instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.PP5V_G3H: What is PP5V_G3H? PP5V_G3H is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
hello im working on this machine with full short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
found the culprit on <CAPACITOR>C6998</CAPACITOR>. after i replaced <CAPACITOR>C6998</CAPACITOR> i got <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present, now the device can able to switch on 20v. 
but still not able to turn on. (can feel now taptic is clicking.)
i did some voltage testing everything is normal excepts on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> is missing did also diode testing is not shorted. 
also tried replace <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> from donor board (same board model number)
btw:measured also <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> before i tooked <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> from this donor board is present.

kinda no idea whats the next step. 
TIA

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get all voltages, even S3 and S0, but no <SIGNAL>1V8_SUS</SIGNAL>?
That's really strange, it is enabled by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
Check <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR>/02/04 and <CAPACITOR>C7904</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
sorry my mistake not all voltages are present
missing voltages:
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> not shorted
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> not shorted
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> not shorted
machine is getting only 20v 0.17amp stuck here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?
Should be good to post all voltages you get, to know where the board is stuck in power on sequence.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If you get S0 voltages, there must be more coils with voltage.
The RAM must get voltage in S3 already (L7900).
Check L7960 and L8000/20/50.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 92821, member: 682"]
If you get S0 ***L8000/20/50.
[/QUOTE]
all coils that u mentioned is zero voltage (not shorted)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> high, so <SIGNAL>1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> is enabled; <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> MUST generate <SIGNAL>1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> at L8020.
Check <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR>-23...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
yes i have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>  but i dont have <SIGNAL>1V8_SUS</SIGNAL>. 
L8020 is 0V both sides not shorted diodde to ground is 0.410
Checked <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR>-23 0V not shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Checked resistors for short?
I don't understand that.
Did you check if mentioned resistors have correct (ohm) value?
If yes, then change <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

correct (ohm) value?

<RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR>-23 ohm value is normal both are having 100k
as i mentioned to my previous post <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> was replaced from working donor board already.
now itried to reball <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> just to make sure i didnt put properly, but i still not getting <SIGNAL>1V8_SUS</SIGNAL>
i tried also reball and putback the original <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> <SIGNAL>1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> still zero volts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
